ten_quan: HoÃ ng Ty Group - Äáº·c sáº£n Tráº£ng BÃ ng - Nguyá»…n Há»¯u Cáº§u
noi_dung:
A nice place for a local taste. Vegetables are fresh and abundant. This place also offers a super nice dessert called Che Khuc Bach.

Prices: reasonable for the location and the amount of food it offers. But also remember if you eat mainly meat, it will get expensive since the idea of the dish is wrap and roll, which means you should consume a lot of veggie together with a piece of meat. The veggie here is special, supposed to come from a mountainous area in VN, which you can not find in other resemblances around VN. 

The place can get quite noisy because people tend to come in big groups.

Location: very central.

noi_dung: It was an ok dining experience. The food was good but was not spectacular compared to next door. We had the crab spring rolls which were good but not piping hot. The crab vermecelli was nice, it had a good amount of crab meat and crab roe, however it was small in size compared to next door. The star of the show was the whole crab in tamarind sauce, messy to eat but my word the sauce was great and the crab meat was succulent! All in all, reasonable experience but could be better in regards to the spring roll and vermecelli.

We wanted to try the cua lá»™t chiÃªn bá»™t (soft shell crabs) and also we decided to add the cháº£ giÃ² cua biá»ƒn (deep fried crab spring rolls) and the miáº¿n xÃ o cua (vermicelli noodles stir-fried with crab meat)

Interestingly, the main event turned out not to be the main event! That is, the soft shell crabs were good â€“ but not amazing. (What was all the internet fuss about??) Meaty, yes. Crispy, yes. A bit expensive, yes. A tad oily, yes. World class memorable, not really.

And the deep fried crab spring rolls â€¦ so-so. (Iâ€™d skip these next time â€“ if there should be a next time).

But the main event turned out to be the vermicelli noodles stir-fried with crab meat.. So much crab meat! And sweet and flavorful! And the glass noodles â€“ done to perfection, al dente. A mildly flavored dish that allowed the subtle flavor of the fresh crabmeat to shine. Very nice indeed. This is their signature dish in my opinion.

If we return, the miáº¿n xÃ o cua with a glass of beer or iced tea would be just fine for a yummy, reasonably-priced dinner.

And the search for that perfect soft shell crab dinner (other than in my own living room) shall continue. 
Overall, an interesting eatery thatâ€™s retained its simple local ambiance, but become tourist-targeted in its menu and prices. Prices are very high by local Saigon standards, but reasonable for a â€œtouristâ€ restaurant.

ten_quan: Lubu Restaurant - Tháº£o Äiá»n
noi_dung:
Welcoming a new kid on the block, Lubu is a chic and chill restaurant that opened last November! 

Located at the quiet neighbourhood of Thao Dien, you can look forward to a great place to unwind over a great selection of wine and great food too!

The menu is mainly Mediterranean in flavours. For starters, we highly recommend the fresh oysters from Nha Trang. Simply sublime! 

The seared swordfish and pork tenderlion are some of the main entrees we would also recommend. The food absolutely value for money especially with the quality and taste wrapped in them! 

By the time we mouthed our starters and appetitizers, we had no room for desserts. So we can't comment on the sweet stuffs. But do make your way to this new restaurant. It will be worth your dong and time!

Food type and taste: Mediterranean cuisine- 4.5/5 stars 
Price: High range 
Ambience: Indoor and al fresco dining. Great for dates.
